text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 11.3.27, Disclosure of Returns and Return Information to Grand Juries.

Editorial changes have been made throughout to update IRM/statute/organizational references and to make the text easier to follow. Web and citation references were added/updated throughout to make the text easier to research in electronic media.

Revised the title of IRM 11.3.27.1 to Program Scope and Objectives, to properly reﬂect the information communicated in this subsection. Included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles:
a. IRM
, Background - Added information from prior section
to this new subsection to provide the background of policies pertaining to disclosures to Federal, State, local grand juries in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code. b. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities pertaining to the IRS disclosure process to Federal, State, and local grand juries. c. IRM
, Responsibilities - This IRM applies to all IRS and Chief Counsel personnel contractors who provide records under the provisions of IRM
Disclosure of Official Information. d. IRM
, Acronyms - Compiled a list of acronyms pertaining to the disclosure of information to Federal, State, and local grand juries. e. IRM
, Related Resources - Added related resources applicable to the disclosure to Federal, State, and local grand juries process.
All other subsequent subsections were renumbered accordingly.
All Operating Divisions and Functions.
The Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library can be found at: https://organization.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/vldp/default.aspx.
Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards
Disclosure of Returns and Return Information to Grand Juries
Program Scope and Objectives
of Returns and Return Information to Juries 11.3.27
Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy.
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
The following is a list of the acronyms that are used in this IRM section:

) Allegations that federal tax laws have been violated are presented to a grand jury by the Department of Justice or the Office of the United States Attorney. These allegations may have been investigated by the IRS and forwarded for further investigation or prosecution to the Department of or the United States Attorney. (
) In some cases, allegations of federal tax law violations arise during the jury’s inquiry into other federal violations. In these cases, the assistance of IRS may be requested. (

) For tax administration, the IRS may disclose returns and return information the Department of Justice for use in a federal grand jury proceeding: a. On its own motion if the tax case has been referred to the Department Justice by the IRS or b. In response to a written request of the Attorney General, Deputy General or an Assistant Attorney General in a tax case that has not referred to the Department of Justice, if the returns or return relate to a person named in the request and the request explains the for the disclosure. 11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
) Occasionally grand juries are convened to investigate violations of both tax and non-tax laws. In these situations, follow the procedures outlined in Grand
above, and IRM
, Disclosure to Federal Officers and Employees for Tax Administration Purposes. (
) Rule

(e) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, generally provides matters occurring before the grand jury are secret. For convenience, of Grand Jury occurring before the grand jury” will be referred to as grand jury information. (
) IRS personnel gaining access to grand jury information pursuant to (
) may not disclose this information except as authorized or in accordance exceptions to the general rule of secrecy. (
) Disclosures otherwise prohibited by Rule

(e), other than the deliberations the vote of any grand juror, may be made to: a. An attorney for the government for use in the performance of such ney’s duty, and b. Such government personnel (including a state) as are deemed by an attorney for the government to assist an attorney for the in the performance of such attorney’s duty to enforce federal criminal See IRM
), Disclosures in Conformity with an Ex Parte Order. (
) Grand jury information may also be disclosed to the IRS in accordance with Rule
(e) court order. While it is still grand jury information, it also becomes return information. The use and disclosure of this information must be tent with both IRC §
and the Rule
(e) order. Example: If a Rule
(e) order authorizes IRS use of certain grand jury for civil tax purposes, this information may be used only as provided the order, and to the extent permitted by IRC §
As a result, the GAO, a state, or another federal agency would not be entitled to it under IRC §
unless permitted in the Rule
(e) order. The IRS still disclose the information to the Department of Justice under IRC §

) as necessary in the litigation of the IRS’s civil tax cases. The decision to issue a Rule
(e) order permitting the IRS to grand jury information for civil purposes is in the discretion of the court having supervision over the grand jury. (

) It is important to distinguish grand jury information from returns and return in- formation the IRS obtained independently. The independently obtained information, even if exactly the same as the grand jury information, is not governed by Rule
(e) and may be disclosed in accordance with IRC §
Information supplied to a grand jury by the IRS from sources independent of the grand jury process may be used for the criminal purposes of the grand and the civil purposes of the IRS. (
) Additionally, Rule
(e) does not prohibit the disclosure of the fact of existence of grand jury information to other IRS personnel with a need to know that fact. See IRM

, for a discussion of Grand Jury Information. Example: Disclosure Managers or TIGTA Auditors performing a functional review may be told that they cannot look at a document because it contains secret grand jury information.
If a Rule
(e) order authorizes IRS use of certain grand jury information for civil tax purposes, this information may be used only as provided in the order, and to the extent permitted by IRC §
As a result, the GAO, a state, or another federal agency would not be entitled to access it under IRC §
unless permitted in the Rule
(e) order. The IRS can still disclose the information to the Department of Justice under IRC §

(e) order permitting the IRS to use grand jury information for civil purposes is in the discretion of the court having supervision over the grand jury.

Information supplied to a grand jury by the IRS from sources independent of the grand jury process may be used for the criminal purposes of the grand and the civil purposes of the IRS. (
) Additionally, Rule
(e) does not prohibit the disclosure of the fact of existence of grand jury information to other IRS personnel with a need to know that fact. See IRM
, for a discussion of Grand Jury Information.
Example: Disclosure Managers or TIGTA Auditors performing a functional review may be told that they cannot look at a document because it contains secret grand jury information.
of Returns and Return Information to Juries 11.3.27

Special care should be taken to document sources of information as the IRS may have to prove that evidence used for civil purposes was properly obtained under a Rule 6(e) order or was obtained independently of the grand jury.

Questions regarding whether information is considered to be grand jury infor- mation should be directed, as appropriate, to functional management, Criminal Tax of Chief Counsel, or the government attorney coordinating the grand jury.
) IRS employees may be authorized to assist the Department of Justice in a non-tax grand jury investigation. (

) An IRS employee assisting the United States Attorney in a non-tax grand proceeding may not access returns or return information or disclose any returns or return information to the attorney for the government in connection with the investigation, unless disclosure is authorized by IRC §
(c) or (i), some other IRC §
exception (for example, IRC §
)). The provi- sions of IRC §
(h) cannot be used in these cases, unless a related call is made. See IRM
, Disclosure of Federal Officers and for Tax Administration. (

) Information that an IRS employee receives or develops while acting as an agent of a non-tax grand jury is not return information. The information is grand jury information and may not be used for civil or criminal tax purposes independently of the grand jury, unless a Rule
(e) order permits the use. (
) An IRS summons should not be used and personnel should not present selves as IRS employees. See IRM
, Details of CI Employees to Other Agencies, and IRM
, Issuance and Use Of The Badge, regarding use of IRS credentials in these cases. (
) There are no restrictions under Rule
(e) on the use of grand jury that is disclosed in a judicial or administrative proceeding and made a part the public record pertaining to that proceeding. (
) IRC §
restrictions may apply, however, to any information gathered by IRS in carrying out tax administration duties. See IRM
, Which Has Become Public Record, for further discussion of disclosures to tax information that has been made a matter of public record.

Information that an IRS employee receives or develops while acting as an agent of a non-tax grand jury is not return information. The information is grand jury information and may not be used for civil or criminal tax purposes independently of the grand jury, unless a Rule 6(e) order permits the use.

IRC §6103 restrictions may apply, however, to any information gathered by the IRS in carrying out tax administration duties. See IRM 11.3.11.13, Information Which Has Become Public Record, for further discussion of disclosures related to tax information that has been made a matter of public record.
